i don’t understand why children under are allowed unsupervised internet access in the first place my siblings and i never spent a dime of our parents money like this because it wasn’t available our brain’s capability to entertain itself also remained in tact i personally think it is a disservice to your children to be putting them on ipads in the first place but i’ve heard a bunch of “pay it back” or “keep the ipads with grandma for grandma time” which seem to be easier than “quitting screens all together” if it seems that unrealistic to unscreen your children doesn’t that seem like a problem i’d like to say im not old a lot of kids my age growing up had access to family computers game boy nintendo ds tablets and even early age smart phones my parents didn’t want their children addicted to over producing serotonin so when i begged and begged and begged for a flip phone or an ipod or a tablet they didn’t budge it’s your job as a parent to think of the long term affects of their childhood edit i’d also like to add that i’m not saying all this to shame your parenting or anything i don’t have kids what i can say though is in comparison to my essentially screen free childhood my adult life is very affected by the attachment i have with my phone it’s very difficult to believe in myself trust myself entertain myself i suffer from social anxiety new depressive states new attitude sass issues i’ve always been a little snappy but it’s worse when i’m trying to cleanse my internet usage and my creative abilities have nearly vanished because of their lack of use aside from digital

sometimes kids just love the nostalgia but are too afraid to ask for it themselves i remember being a kid and doing a girl guide trip to our local museum where we got to sleep over in the science area do a museum wide scavenger hunt in the dark one night years later we were sitting around at a meeting reminiscing on that night and eventually i was like “hey let’s ask if we can do it again ” so we did and they ended up making it a program wide thing where like units showed up and i was asked to write about it for the paper of course us older kids pretended it was so dumb the whole time but we all admitted later that we loved the whole thing

i definitely hovered over her more i didn't allow her to do some things at ages that i have since let her little or brother do who is years younger than her i was very naive as a child and a teenager and i didn't want her to be the same i tried to prepare her for all the horrible people in the world and in doing so i projected my own insecurities and fears onto her luckily she is so emotionally mature and exceptionally intelligent that she does not have the same fears and insecurities however i realize i shouldn't have been trying to shield her as much because i could have very well given her the same fears and insecurities that i do have when she was she moved to montana to live with her dad because she had spent her first years of life with me and she missed her dad and her sisters over there and the biggest reason was that their high school only had about students whereas our high school here has over students so i agreed to let her move and since she's moved i've learned a lot of things i kind of put her in that older sister guaranteed babysitter role that she didn't need to be in i expected her to behave about years older than she always was because she was so intelligent and she was so mature i often forgot what a typical child her age would look like or how they would act because she never acted her actual age she always acted older so when we were at the mall or something for example if she had some behavior that was not typical for her but baby typical for an year old when she was she would get in trouble because we felt that she should be acting more like a year old so she ended up kind of getting small punishments because she wasn't acting her age in our eyes because we saw her as a year old but she really was acting her age and her own eyes because she really was an year old does that make sense it's really hard to put it all into writing because a lot of it seems very very small when you just write it out and list it i don't think that really shows the seriousness and the gravity of what i did to harm our relationship she was never abused physically or emotionally but she did feel like her stepdad and i expected way too much of her so she always felt like she would never be able to live up to her expectations she craved positive attention and we gave her plenty we thought but she has told me that she never felt like we were truly proud of her because we didn't act with as much excitement after her plays or when she aced a test or something like that a lot of the struggle for most of her childhood we thought related to the fact that she was years older than her little brother so even though we were treating them the same as each other as far as how we punished them or what kinds of things they were allowed to have it was at different times for example when my daughter was five that's when she started doing chores she started with simple things like putting her own clothes away taking out the bathroom garbage and maybe wiping down the bathroom sink by the time her brother was five she was so she had more age appropriate chores and her little brother had the same chores she had when she was five well in her nine year old brain she thought it was unfair because she had more to do than her brother i tried to explain to her that when she was five she had the same amount of chores but it was difficult for her to understand because she didn't remember well she has kind of felt like her little brother got better treatment his whole life because of things like that where i did treat him exactly the same as i traded her when she was his age she feels like we often favored him things like when her brother played baseball we would all attend games and we would cheer and tell him how great he did and all that stuff after the game but she never played a sport she was always in drama and i absolutely loved it she is so insanely talented and she has a real passion for acting and directing and writing but you don't really cheer during a play you don't shout over the crowd yeah good job way to remember your lines nice job talking loud enough for everyone to hear you but we said all of those things and more when it was over we gushed at how great she played her role but to her it didn't feel the same i can kind of understand that as i was in marching and concert band growing up and my brothers played sports my parents hated instrumental music and they absolutely loved sports but i recognize the fact that my parents were every one of my band concerts they always made sure i had my instrument and the things i needed to be able to play it they always came to parades or band competitions to watch me even though it was so dull and boring for them and they always told me how great i did and how proud they were of me and i could tell it was forced but it didn't negate the fact that they really were proud of me they just didn't know how to show it because they had only ever attended sporting events i guess she always felt that we weren't as proud of her as we were of her brother playing baseball which is completely untrue but i guess we didn't show it in a way that she could see it there are some things that she has told me that i don't understand or i don't agree with her viewpoint of how we acted or reacted or treated her in general but i recognize and understand that her feelings are hers alone and they're not for me to understand they're only for me to accept and i can try to ask for clarification and i can try to get some sort of understanding as to what i did wrong or where i went wrong and i might never get that all i know is that my daughter and i are not as close as we used to be and it hurts and if i could go back and do it again i would remind myself every single day not to make the same mistakes

can someone tell me i haven't failed as a parent roblox content so i have talked to my year old daughter about online safety in depth no names no ages or location ive also talked to her about grown adults that pretend to be kids so no pretend kissing or boyfriends in roblox she plays in the room with me and i'm always around i monitor her chats ive allowed the chats to happen because she talks with school friends and ive actually honestly found it helps her with spelling writing today i found out of her online non school friends she engages in sex with asking opened ended questions and reading the logs the most she understands is its kissing in bed but the people talking to her obviously know what it is they have found ways around the chat moderation features to type inappropriate stuff i'm disturbed and upset i immediately blocked the offending players she was devastated over losing friends i explained its not her fault shes not being punished but i cant allow others to speak to her like that and that she needs to report them if they do i explained that sex was how people made babies and that its not something someone her age needs to be doing or talking about im considering blocking the chat feature but i know she chats with her friends i feel like a failure as a parent this pandemic has been hard and honestly tablet time is the only baby sitter i get now ive spent the morning sobbing feeling like the worst mom how could i let this happen my husband is obviously upset but he also thinks she doesnt fully understand it so i shouldnt be so hard on myself thoughts advice i feel like my daughter has been molested even though its virtual *a much undeserved silver y'all have honestly pulled me thru one of my roughest day and i'm beyond appreciative

i have an almost year old who's been on roblox for years now i didn't open up the chat for him until he was or so but even then like you i'm constantly monitoring activity asking what they might be talking about who he's playing with etc just keeping the communication open and casual so he's more likely to be honest i've not seen sex stuff but i've seen bullying but as a s kid who was an adolescent in the age of chat rooms i remember well being approached online about sex stuff i didn't read through the other comments but maybe it's a good idea to communicate with her about what it means this is a seriously complicated matter on one hand you wouldn't want to shut down a young girl's sexuality exploration as a message but on the other hand it's the internet also my son is an only child and roblox friends have been his sole outlet and friendly communication during quarantine so when he does something outside of roblox that deserves a consequence we have a hard time taking that away although we do sometimes regardless my husband and i decided to keep an open line of communication with him about things he's bound to see online we keep tons of parental controls on his computer so we still have the reigns and we talk to him every day about what's going on online so far he's stayed incredibly open and honest maybe this is isn't advise or anything but i know the feeling while we haven't seen sex stuff some of the roblox communities worry me royale high and adopt me in particular we encourage him to get into communities where there are challenges and team work gah i guess i'm not helping good luck raising adolescents is tricky business

i audit the chat nightly for my child there are parental controls but even year olds mine is also can figure their way around them pretty fast they are better at this stuff than we are it's like anything else as long as you're paying attention to what's going on and checking in on it it's more or less harmless and a nice way for the kids to connect outside of school during screen time the sicko's don't go away when they're older though so in some ways it's beneficial to be explaining to them now why you're auditing chat every night and that not everybody on the internet is who they say they are so they should only trust their friends is plenty old enough for that conversation

just say no i know how unhelpful that sounds but there really is no way around it at this age you opened pandora's box by allowing her to start the game in the first place you need very clear expectations and rules for how long and when she gets to play use timers enforce it maybe she earns the game for a positive action whatever works for you make sure you explain *why* videogames are limited brain junk food no time for school sleep no family connection etc her brain is addicted to the stimulus and it is a novelty it might take time to wean her off so you could start reducing her play time gradually if you try and cut her off cold turkey it will likely just lead to power struggles and anger she likes this and you allowed it so now arbitrarily taking it away is going to feel very unfair and confusing the ultimate goal is to achieve a predictable mutually agreed outcome in which she can have her game and once she sort of gets used to *not* having it constantly and starts finding other ways to fill her time she might not ask for it as much fyi you should monitor her activity closely in the game my kids aren't into this one personally but i have heard it is possible for creeps to interact with kids if they have public access i don't know how it works because as i said this isn't a favorite in our house but you should look into it

mine was the same with minecraft though we had a new baby and it kept him occupied during the time he enjoyed it but he began to spend all of his time doing exactly what your daughter is doing and his behavior was suffering too just epic meltdowns super moody and not himself because of meltdowns tantrums we took away the playstation and tablet for two weeks at a time first few days were brutal but he started going back to the things he used to love drawing independent play going outside etc he obviously needed more direction and help finding the next task to do to keep him occupied but i don’t regret it then when he would get his tablet and stuff back he would play for awhile and then randomly get bored and do something else much like adults when you decide your indulging too much into something and you try and fill your time with other things that one big thing starts to lose its hold over you you could start with limiting screen time maybe just completely cut out the youtube too that place is garbage and unless you are closely monitoring they’ll be exposed to all sorts of weird shit like peppa pig with blood oozing out of her mouth

if you can step down the screen time i would do that you can also go cold turkey and just limit the time outright but that will cause some distress either way i would be sure that you explain to her that she's not in trouble and not being punished often times taking away electronics is how parents punish so you don't want her thinking she's done something wrong or something to deserve something she enjoys being taken away

so for limiting screen time at my house we don’t use specific amounts of time as that’s not super intuitive but rather times of day on school days my kids are not allowed screen time in the morning or after school they need to get ready in the am and do homework or help out after school then they can play but after supper they can have screen time until an hour before bedtime then it’s time to get ready for bed and read for half hour or so this gets them about an hour mins a day for screens on weekdays depending on when we have supper weekends they have screen time before i get up in the morning then not again until after supper so probably hours on the weekend i find because it’s our routine they don’t really fight me on it as they know when there will be time for screens i do make some exceptions for my teenager as he wants to use more of his free time to play online chess and logic games i also make exceptions if someone is sick the weather is bad or we are all feeling seriously burned out but most of the time that is our routine and it works well

you are the parent so you decide how long she uses it for will she like limits no does she like being told what to do or told off no it'll be hard at first to wean her off it but do it there will be lots of i'm bored and maybe tantrums but you set limits my daughter is and only gets minutes on her tablet she would also play for hours then be so overly stimulated that she can't calm down so she knows it's limited she also knows she has to do her chores or tasks in order to get tablet time so it's a reward for behaving

she's so capable of understanding basic rules sit her down and talk to her about the new rules around roblox and why you're doing this tell her set times ie when you cook dinner when you are cleaning xyz kids that age don't really understand the concept of actual time so associate screen time to events like cooking or folding laundry once you establish this stick to it it'll suck for a while because once it sinks in she won't like it but tell her she's free to do any other activity other than things associated to a screen
send her outside to play lock the doors don't open the doors until dinner my dad did that with me and brothers i do it with my boys the back yard is a magical place

i like this strategy we really try not to do limits either however we do other activities and have other responsibilities so when we have free time it is free time my kids don't always choose to use it all on screen time but sometimes they do working on a healthy balance that allows other things we enjoy in life is what works in our house

i have a year old daughter and i will never give my daughter a phone untill she is plus she only allow to have hr hr screen time per day the rest of the day is play time and crafts if she is on screen it only can be educational games or educational videos it will take her to weeks to stop begging for screen if you set a restriction my trick is if she whine beg and cry for it she will lose screen time today and tomorrow i used screen time as a reward if she is behaving good that day and she will get screen time afternoon if she gets upset when it is done and i turn it off she will lose tomorrow's screen time and i have gone days and weeks of no screen sometimes if she gets real bad we had month no screen before her behavior is excellent the pass months you can let her listen to aduio books when there's no screen but it can make them tired and sleepy if they listen to it for long period

roblox and similar games i was wondering how other parents deal with online games such as roblox my two kids love roblox and spend a lot of time on the app my wife has concerns about the fact that they can chat with other users she fears that they can chat with strangers and we can't see it this came to light today when my oldest was excited that she got to chat with a roblox youtuber she follows it was like she met a minor celebrity her excitement was squashed when my wife got upset that she was talking to strange men and what were they talking about in an accusatory tone when i tried to discuss it i essentially got yelled at and my daughter ran off in tears i'm not really sure how to address the situation the chatting does give me concern but at the same time i know how popular the app is and how fun it is for kids just curious what other parents do

my husband and i are big gamers and we have met some of our best friends online through games the secret is making sure you have open conversations with your kids so they know what is appropriate and what isnt also we have taken a big stance on playing with our son so when he plays online we join him not always but a lot and we can see what exactly is happening this also leads to us being able to tell him when things are inappropriate there are dangers but we personally feel that just staying away from them won't teach him how to recognize the dangers and to avoid them in the future

my kids love it too and it's been kinda cool for my oldest because we're in our second lockdown due to the virus and he gets some sort of interaction with his friends one thing they've had drummed into them is they're not allowed to accept friend requests from people they don't know or chat to people they don't know when they were at school they got the usernames of some of their friends in order to interact with them in the game i didn't let my kids go on it until i thought they were old enough to handle the potential negatives i explained that there are some people who aren't really who they're pretending to be i explained that there are some grownups on there pretending to be kids and that they were kinda spoiling it for everyone which luckily they understood but i make sure i'm around when they're on the site too i've heard of people setting up their own username so they can explore the games themselves and what their kids are doing i've found that engaging my kids in conversation about what they do online and showing an interest to be more productive than outright banning or being overly negative as it gets them talking more freely about what they're doing that enables you to have more conversations about safety and appropriate behaviour
i turned off the chat in roblox for my dd for this reason and it helped until she told me she was on a server with roblox character people having sex soooo that got cut off real quick
yikes

gamer dad here there are two different elements to your situation that need to be considered one is screen time and addiction games just like tv and books are designed to get your attention with an interesting story and like puzzles jigsaws and board games they're designed to make you want to keep trying to win the challenge on top of that they have replayability and are never exactly the same each time you play it young kids cannot be expected to self regulate against this you must set boundaries no matter how much they beg and whine explain to your kids why the boundaries are important to you but don't give in the other element is the online social network built into some games just like facebook your kids are messaging and talking with other people through the game do you know exactly who they are talking to just because the other person's profile says they are doesn't mean it's true i do let my kids play minecraft but only on my own server that can only be accessed inside my house so they get to do all kinds of fun things within our family world building sharing and problem solving and yes after an hour they are very unhappy to be torn away but i know what it's like and i know the feeling passes to be honest i'd still prefer they spent their screen time playing games instead of watching the nth repeat of some animated cartoon i haven't used roblox but it does look like they have some offline features you could look into that

roblox hi parents for those of you who may not be familiar with roblox it's a website application that is kindof like an mmorpg for kids there's hundreds of different games from survivor tv show clones to fashion shows to zombie games its free to play but there is paid content as well the site is specifically targeted to kids and teens there's a chat feature that can be disabled and it is somewhat heavily auto moderated i want to take a moment and share my experiences with it along with a question or two and to invite you to do the same my year old and year old have been playing games on the platform for a while and both seem to love it recently the year old has gotten interested in the social aspect friends and chat as i said the chat feature can be disabled and i explained to her that if we run into problems with chat that we'd turn it off we've worked hard to set expectations so that everyone is clear on the front end the friend aspect is rather like the steam game platform and you can request that people become your friend it doesn't seem to have much impact other than that you can see if they are in a game and join a game that they are in as well as messaging the computer monitor faces our family living room so its easy to see at a glance what's going on i don't tend to hover constantly but when she's reading or typing in the chat window i make a point to give it a fairly frequent look it is as much an exercise in guarding against nefariousness as it is in trying to help and guide her in understanding online interactions we have of course talked about safety and predators online but tbh i'm more worried about hard or soft bullying online which we also talk about one of the things that i'm really working with her on is this friends thing there's one person that she's befriended that has a cute sounding name along the lines of unicornsparkle the year old is delighted when this other person is in the same game with her and talks to me about this person i get the feeling that she's drawn to this person largely by their name and avatar outfit and less by any quantitative qualities i don't mind that but i'm working to help her get an understanding of what it means to be friends with someone in an online setting she has expressed an interest in learning to touch type so we've found a couple of resources for that i think this may help her now and later as her typing is pretty slow and basic and i've noticed a couple of times that her chat responses come so delayed as to lose all context and once or twice have been misunderstood or misconstrued here's some of the rules and expectations that we have setup for her * do not give out your name we let her come up with a 'nickname' so that she can offer her name if asked without giving out her personal information * don't give out other personal info location etc someone asked her age the other day and she was quick to not give her actual age but after thinking about it a moment age doesn't seem like 'bad' information * no secrets * she won't be in trouble for anything that anyone posts or that she sees if she has questions about anything that she saw or read she can ask and we'll talk about them no judging * we expect her to be kind just as she would to someone in rl no namecalling making fun bullying etc * if someone says things that are unkind to her or other people she should avoid them and can let us know standing up against bullying is also encouraged * she uses the computer with our permission and asks if she's not sure of something we have the philosophy that there are dangers on the internet but we don't want to fall into the trap of believing that a child abductor is hiding behind every bush she's up to speed on safety in that regard and it is relatively easy to protect her from this threat she is far more likely to run into an unkind person or bully and it is more difficult to protect her from that i feel that by teaching her about these things early that i can help arm her with the information that she needs to be safe and healthy and have respect for herself and others in an online setting other parents what have been your experiences with roblox positive negative or otherwise if your children are into roblox at what age did they become interested in the social aspect of it and what did do you allow thanks edit format and spelling

my son and daughter both play son is and daughter will be in august basically same setup and rules as you have no personal details no bullying our daughter has slept and bounded past the kids in her kindergarten class in termsof reading and spelling partially as a result of her gaming wife and i join the games often it's been positive for us with a few learning opportunities for the kids

as a vetran teacher i have a few suggestions talk to your daughter about internet safety and etiquette in general [be internet awesome ] have an honest conversation about predators the internet is like being at an amusement park you may alk to the person in li e next to you but you do not give them identifiable information [videos for kids and under about safety predators and what to] get the user name of the person talking to her on roblox contact roblox and request that this account and all future accounts created by this person be blocked from accessing your daughter also let them know you suspect it is a predator if parents and kids don't report the company doesn't know find out what she enjoys about roblox minecraft is similar but from what my students tell me safer start building an open relationship with your daughter she needs to know she can tell you about her life without judgment or punishment leave her in school you can not control her actions she is an individual with her own thoughts and feelings if you pull her out of school most likely she will resent you please excuse any spelling or grammar errors i am the sleep deprived parent of a newborn

i think pulling her out would be a little aggressive but ultimately you are the parent have you had the internet safety discussion in depth my parents always told me that everyone was a stranger and could be dangerous but never went deep into it i spent years of my life chatting online with strangers some probably were dangerous but i knew not to give personal information and it all stayed on the screen it’s unrealistic in this day and age to expect no contact from computers i mean i met my husband online even the epitome of stranger danger but if you teach her safety and monitor her usage you will have better success in the long run than shutting it out completely

despite your feelings of concern being valid all your behavior is doing is teaching your daughter how to hide from you and turning her into a better liar seek some professional help for both of you to learn how to build trust between you before it’s too late children whose parents tightly restrict their privacy just learn how to keep better secrets and will develop a lifelong inability to trust others especially you

common sense media has some lessons free you just have to create an account that could help guide the conversation i work with middle school aged students and this is a hard age with regard to virtual friendships they cannot tell what is safe or not and they feel absolutely that they can so confronting them ultimately backfires common sense media helps them to see the warning signs and facilitates a conversation that doesn’t make them defensive it’s such a difficult time to be a parent and a tween there is no rule as to when or how much social media is safe and then they compare to friends with more lax parents and they feel rebellious and hurt that they don’t have the same come at the conversation with immense compassion try to start with several ways you see their point and then see if you can bring up why you’re concerned and see if they’d like to dialogue with you solutions that feel safe if she has buy in and becomes comfortable knowing you will listen she’ll return to you honestly when a weird situation online comes up again good luck

pulling her out of school goes way too far home schooling is hard work and you need to do it for the right reasons if you do it just to shelter her from outside influences you will do her a huge disservice you won't be able to keep her safe from the world at least not forever and you need to come to terms with that one day she'll leave your home and enter the real world if you never expose her to anything risky or dangerous until then she'll be completely screwed because she'll have no idea what's out there and can't protect herself instead of trying to control her in this way prepare her for these dangers and teach her how to keep herself safe kids don't grow an extra part of their brain which contains all the knowledge on how to handle the world and take care of themselves the night of their th birthday these are skills that need to be taught and practiced for years and years and years and sheltering her is the exact opposite of what you need to do to teach her these skills sit down with her and go over the chat with her explain what concerns you about it for example that he only told her his age after your daughter already told him she's explain that there are predators out there who mask themselves as kids in order to try and gain kids' affection so that they can sexually exploit them tell her that some people use being suicidal as emotional blackmail so that you do what they want because you're scared of hurting them so much that they end up hurting themselves tell her that even if someone is genuinely suicidal she shouldn't do things she's not comfortable with and that if a suicidal person does end up hurting themselves it's never her fault explain that some predators specifically use roblox to target kids because they know that a lot of the players are year olds etc have the entire internet safety talk with her not telling anyone her name or where she lives not posting pictures of herself or that could identify the area she lives in not giving random internet strangers her number or address etc ultimately you can't keep her safe by controlling her maybe you can do it temporarily but in the long run it'll end up doing a lot more harm than good teach her how to keep herself safe you need to focus on raising a future adult

please do not pull her out of school talk to the school about kids accessing internet strangers under their watch the best way to protect her is not to punish her and isolate her from her peers but to educate educate educate her

eh alright i’ll bite the legal minimum age to sign up for accounts on most social media platforms even ones that are going to be “monitored” by parents or are “family” accounts is thirteen whilst there may not be any major crack downs happening to address the large amount of underaged and unmonitored users that doesn’t mean letting your kid have one is harmless or necessary plain old texting on whatever built in messaging app that comes with every phone is still something people do every day without requiring any fancy stickers or reactions from another app to keep it fun at the same time however there’s gonna be a day where your kid is going to need a phone and her impulse control issues will no longer be an excuse to not give her one though that doesn’t necessarily mean she can just put whatever she wants on it without you knowing being unable to see what she’s doing iphones can be set as a child account that you can have a access and control over from your phone that she will not be able to easily bypass without you knowing many other types of phones have apps or similar system programming that allow the same level of monitoring with very few workarounds even the most tech savvy kid would have trouble figuring out without leaving a trail behind for you to follow ultimately it’s your choice as to when if your daughter gets a phone of her own and what she can do on it but educating her on cyber safety and what’s expected of her before giving her a phone will be more beneficial in the long run rather than just holding out until it’s absolutely necessary or she’s old enough to pay for her own and having her be glued to it

the research about the negative effects of social media is so abundant it seems negligent at this point to give unlimited access to technology after knowing this the # advice my high school students give me is to keep my daughter away from devices and hold off on giving her a phone for as long as possible even teenagers are self aware enough to realize how bad it is for them

i think there needs to be a balance yes you don’t want her addicted to her screen but you don’t want to make it so she’s unable to connect with her friends on a relatable level so much of childhood is common experience and currently you’re denying her the ability to relate to her peers the danger with this attitude is that you’re making it this taboo thing the likelihood of her going online in secret and then not telling you if she encounters something wrong or dangerous online bullying predators porn becomes higher because she hasn’t been taught internet safety and she’s breaking the rules don’t set her up to fail or set her up to keep secrets life should be about balance i have a surprising number of friends who struggle with a good relationship with food because their parents banned certain kinds instead of teaching moderation and self control imo — she needs to learn the importance of moderation and maybe earning her screen time when she’s done her work rather than denying it to her completely

meh everything should be regulate to an extent but really name one job that doesn’t require use of technology do you know how much more valuable employers find employees that can troubleshoot said technology preserve the youth and prepare her for adulthood man parenting bites sometimes

to start i think you’re doing great i don’t know that anyone has a tried and true answer to any of this all we have are opinions that said as someone who lives in silicon valley i can assure you most parents who work in the tech industry limit their children’s exposures to social media in particular and in some cases do not even allow devices in their rooms family room computer type stuff i know this because i do not hesitate to ask every time i meet someone who works for these companies and i’m never shocked by their answer just angry because they are getting rich off something they know has an incredible downside to others children’s while protecting their own the best they can schools are beginning responsible tablet use in kindergarten now so that these kids can learn how to use them for educational purposes so between that and their limited use at home they’re getting plenty of exposure i know about five years ago there were signs in the middle schools here that said “wait until th” meaning wait until at least th grade to get them a phone or allow social media use i think maturity and responsible use has a lot to do with it and that comes with age perhaps someone else can update us on if that’s still the case regardless a lot of kids are being targeted on these platforms now by dealers trying to sell them prescriptions pills that are actually laced with fentanyl it literally just happened to audrina partridge’s year old niece this week and it’s led of an increase in shocking overdoses everywhere from young teens who are just curious and trying things that we might have found in our parents medicine cabinets once upon a time this is becoming a scary reality that a lot of people don’t talk about so regardless of what you decide please discuss this with your daughter so she knows how dangerous it is in the event any of her friends who do have social media are targeted
no right answer both yes and no can be correct in this case but if your child has adhd giving her free access to a phone is like giving an alcoholic a gift brandy you need to keep that in check

i’m in the camp of delay especially social media internet communication apps as long as possible year olds don’t need smart phones i know what i did at on extremely limited dial up aol 🥴 that’s enough for me not to willingly participate in this pressured device ridiculousness for tweens i say from a place of not having to deal with it yet and also lots of fear a closely monitored with strict parental controls tablet with limited screen time keeps kids safe in parallel we should teach kids about why and how to navigate the internet safely within those boundaries and what red flags to be on the lookout for no matter how much you govern and lock down devices she’ll have a friend with a parent who won’t bother and you want her to be knowledgeable and confidently stand up for herself and learn from being impulsively sucked into something problematic online i agree with [wait til th] and even then i wouldn’t be opening the youtube flood gates

when i was a kid they said video games and computers would rot our brains those kids who did play were part of the tech boom that generated billions in profits… trying to raised your kids with the techniques and methods of the past are sure to make them different from their peers whether that’s good or bad remains to be seen but we all know that kids are so great with treating kids that are different from them with respect and decency s

my mom did this exact thing so i went behind her back online and got into bad situations i'd let her have supervised time on social media to prevent this also no youtube sounds strange otherwise understandable

you are not doing her a disservice my cousin's daughter has adhd is functionally autistic and has asperger's at yrs of age she would deficate in her pants because she was hooked on youtube and didn't want to stop watching what she was interested in to go to the toilet and her own mother could not smell it or would do anything about it because she didn't want to deal with the possibility of a meltdown i had repeatedly tried to talk to her about it but i was tuned out your daughter knows that you want the best for her and you are allowing her to grow up at her own pace i applaud you for being very good and loving parents

well she’s going to use these apps on her friend’s phones eventually behind your back so your strict rules won’t matter you can’t “preserve her youth” just because you don’t like what the other youth are doing there are genuine safety concerns over using all of those apps but it’s better to teach kids how to use them responsibly my son has adhd and he’s always had access to youtube and roblox just not tiktok yet cause he’s but for the other apps we talk about what’s appropriate and what isn’t and he’s not allowed to chat or comment on anything i also watch the videos he watches with him and play roblox with him too and we set time limits so when he’s played for a long period of time he has to put his device down and go play read or use his imagination for a bit he used to throw a fit about that but he’s much better now and doesn’t fight it so yes you’re doing her a disservice you should educate her on self control what is and isn’t okay to do on these apps and how long is a healthy amount of time to spend on them and have conversations about what she does on these apps to keep open communication if you don’t know how these apps work learn or ask her to teach you cause if you don’t take the lead here her friends will
has she had any therapy around her adhd because if it's impulse control that scares you maybe doing some work around that will help for when you do have to give her a phone one day😬

honestly i have an year old daughter too and she doesn't use any of those things i've never even considered it in our case her friends don't really seem to use a bunch of screens either although maybe they do in their down time and they just don't talk about it but she doesn't facetime anyone and i've never heard kids talking about it i don't think my kids know was tiktok is and i have no idea what roblox is either i would stay the course there's little benefit and lots of documented harm from things like social media screen addiction these tools are meant for adults and even in adult hands they are addictive and are misused in all sorts of ways i really see no benefit for young people in terms of 'social pressure' well i guess when i reflect on that i think the following a the more people who resist the crowd impulse to 'give in' to everything that everyone else is doing the more company those people will have and the easier it becomes for others to follow suite b you are teaching daughter to be critical about things that are popular a valuable lesson in life c a thought what if the 'socially acceptable' or popular thing was something like pornography or drinking and driving for instance as parents our job is to evaluate what is hurtful or helpful to our kids to give them the tools they need through life and then hope they make the best decisions possible i personally view the harms associated with things like social media as being right up there with the examples i listed here so i don't really care if it's become something other people do i'm okay setting a standard for my kids that doesn't follow the norm and teaching them that we can question what is popular that's my two cents

we’re pretty strict compared to my daughters friends parents and our siblings we filter what she watches on youtube and she only plays roblox next to us the one app i will probably not use for a long time for her is tiktok she’s almost she has fun with her friends and can relate to them but doesn’t have unlimited access on anything
naw until late stages of puberty social media are more likely to be a disservice to her

roblox is dangerous imho my kids are only allowed to play with people we actually know and they have been warned not to talk to anybody they don't know not to use their real names never to give out their ages what town we live in etc my kids got phones relatively early and i regret it they're too dependent on them now and i hate it

you’re absolutely not being too strict your kid is always going to tell you they think you are when you tell them no always you’re for sure on the correct side of this argument my yo got a phone this year for communication about the bus situation… an iphone was cheaper than one of those gadgets for kids that have limited capabilities for some annoying reason this kiddo is also adhd and can’t handle having a phone it’s been confiscated more than they’ve had it in their possession for now they’re on the same bus as their older sibling but that changes next year we have it very locked down and there is no social media usage but it’s still managed to cause drama amongst them and their friends we’ve had none of this drama with my oldest personally and some will disagree with me this is very child dependent my oldest was able to handle a phone younger than my middle middle child is and still can’t handle it it’s also ok to make it that way we’ve told all the kids they can have a phone when a it’s needed and b they can handle having one we’re consistent with expectations across the board even though that means they’ll all probably end up with them at different ages

in my opinion you’re doing exactly the right thing especially if she’s got adhd those platforms do more harm than good anyway and in most cases have a minimum age older than your daughter to use i don’t think tiktok does though and it’s the worst one there are kid safe options like gabb phone or bark phone gabb phone looks like a smartphone but has no internet access bark phone does everything a normal smartphone does but it is all parent controlled and parent monitored you can see everything they do on it from your account and they can’t delete texts without permission one of those is what we will be getting my kids when they get to maybe or before that they won’t have anything there’s no need for it if i had my way they wouldn’t get a phone until they are driving but my wife will probably push for a little earlier i’m ok with that as long as it’s one of those phones

i always compare an extreme comparison of course these things to the episode “angel” from black mirror but from personal experience i was sheltered in a similar manner by my grandparents who were scared of everything coming around i’m for reference so like internet and cell phones i couldn’t have myspace or a cell phone or aim i ended up making accounts on friends phones or computers at their houses and became very sneaky my first boyfriend was and i was and he was “happy to teach me everything i’ve been missing out” and absolutely picked me because i ended up being so naive and because i just really wanted to be liked and got bullied for my grandparents overprotectiveness i made bad choices based off of trying to still seem cool to everyone with my yr old she has an iphone and can text or call family and has educational games we don’t do roblox or tiktok or social media in general at of course but by i don’t think i’d be limiting those rather trying to educate her on safe vs unsafe we are very open and i’d rather take the time to educate her on the why the how the who and the what’s about the different dangers and keep an open line of communication and also my family had no idea i’ve told them now as an adult what i did and they were shocked and said “oh no way you were such a sweet innocent kid at we would have noticed ” while i was drinking already smoking cigarettes and having sex by so from that experience of myself i’m very cautious on creating an environment that my kids hide from me my step son is and goes on social medias and video games and has since and we are very open he talks to us when he likes a girl and asks for advice he tells us when people on the game are being too rude he tells us when he thinks he’s hanging with wrong people because they were stealing and he’d like to go home and i think our trust in him and us knowing that he will experience a lot whether we like it our not has helped

ultimately she will using the technology that you are preventing her from using **her entire life** and you should consider teaching her how to use it the worse thing that you can do to someone with adhd is shelter them i just want to put this into a different perspective for you what happens when she goes to college and you're not there to stop certain behavior or impose limitations adhd is not a disease dont treat it as such instead teach her life skills that help her navigate a society that was not made for her and it starts with responsible use of technology **poor impuse control doesnt mean she cant get better** but she needs the opportunity to practice so she can develop her skills

i support you in this there’s a lot of shit online now especially when it comes to people creating their own content i am having that struggle now because the father of my child doesn’t see it that way and won’t support efforts to stop watching youtube videos my son is now picking up a ton of sarcasm and bad attitudes and uncooperative behavior that makes him such a pain to deal with this same behavior is exhibited in those game skits on youtube done by adults i am so tired and it is fighting a losing battle maybe you can find out what it is other kids are watching and parse them before allowing her so she’ll be in the know but you’re right to not want her just absorbing everything

it depends on the child but screen time in our house has been permitted with parental supervision and restriction to age appropriate content as long as there's continued compliance to the house rules surrounding screen time barring any behavioral issues my personal rule for my son has been that as soon as he's autonomous enough to do things on his own i e walk to school by himself go to extracurriculars without my supervision hanging out with friends in the neighborhood without adults watching everybody's every move then a phone is necessary simply as a direct line of communication in case of emergency children with a parent nearby all the time do not need a phone because a parent is available to handle an emergency children without a parent or other trusted adults nearby will need something to act as a resource in case of emergency the age at which this autonomy can be achieved is so individual to every family child that it's just not useful to look at literal age suggestions for any of this i don't like the social media world we live in but that can be monitored the more i thought about removing what is really at its most basic a gps + device just because my kid might find some shitty app to use with his friends the more authoritarian i felt about it i believe it's my job to raise my son around more fulfilling people activities so that shitty apps games don't look so enticing to him when they will fly at him
children do not belong on social media you are doing the right thing there is no reason she needs a regular cellphone great job

check out mommasgonecity on instagram she has a highlight about kids and phones that scares the shit out of me my baby is only weeks but we’re waiting as long as possible also you can look at waittil th instagram you’re not being too strict you’re protecting your child from something their developing brain cannot manage

prepaid flip phone we got one for our kid and it's working just fine for us portable cd player and hand held games and a strict lock down on her ipad there are also nicer minimalist smart phones that only allow text call and email but they're a little pricey and only work with a couple of phone services but it's probably what i'm gonna get for our term when she turns or kids don't need smart phones or social media

keep strong mama i promise you there are similarly minded people out there you are doing your child great service teaching her no and that it's not time yet for these things i truly wish there were more that thought deeper about what they're letting their children be exposed to

my daughter just got her phone at she wasn’t responsible enough before now and sometime she still isn’t i would suggest getting a phone but limiting its use to evening hours after homework is done must be turned in to you at bedtime let her take it if she goes somewhere with friends in case of emergencies etc my daughter would be on social media and getting texts from friends all hours of the night also bullying would occur at all hours too it’s also leverage for chores and such my daughter gets in line real quick when i tell her she is in danger of loosing her phone privileges

don't give in if i could take it back i would you are doing wonderfully i would only caution that you have to prepare for the fact that she is probably getting negative visuals images messages from her friends at school through their phone make sure that she trusts you and wants to tell you what she is seeing in school or else she could start to become bitter and keep secrets

read the next two sentences carefully screens especially smart phones are a dopamine punching addiction adolescent brains are being freshly hardwired for life based on their current experiences do you get why it's so devastating that everyone's letting their kids have smartphones so young their brains are literally being hardwired to be dependent on the dopamine hits coming from those smartphones no wonder depression is on the rise they can't function without the unnatural hits they git because their brains are literally forming around the expectation of having that smartphone around it's actually far worse than an older adult's addiction to their smartphone because us middle aged people made it through the brain formative years without smartphones which means that our need isn't as deeply ingrained or hardwired as the youth's addiction is this is actually some very sinister shit kids having their mental health crippled by this addiction it's nuts
ima say no especially to tiktok

check out the surgeon generals warning to parents that social media is a direct danger to children’s mental health have you not heard of all the children that have committed suicide as young as from online bullying consider how impressionable and underdeveloped a child’s brain is and what exposing them to these things does one example is completely trashing a young girls self esteem comparing themselves to ai fake women this can’t be a real post your job is to protect your child
i personally didnt get a phone until i was i had access to the computer for email and messenger and i'm fine so she will be too

no you’re doing everything right giving your child a phone because “all their friends have it” is a terrible idea and it’s the reason so many parents are awful at their jobs you’re not alienating her and you are protecting her

my daughter is now she can use snapchat on my phone but can only be friends with people *i* have personally met she has hockey friends on there she can use it on her phone for minutes a day she is not allowed to have tiktok or instagram youtube is fully blocked in our house she has pinterest but that’s it i know she comes across some stuff from tiktok but it’s better than having her nose in it constantly she also has adhd and only in the last few months have we given her more freedom with her phone but it still has tons of parental controls on it

i do think most kids are being damaged by how much phone screen time they're being exposed to from a young age but there also is some socially important weight for getting to participate in something all of your peers are doing too could you possibly get her a phone but start her out with some reasonable limits i'm imagining a phone available after school until pm then it's turned into the parents room for overnight type of rule and work from there perhaps with a caveat that if grades fall below a certain average or too many homework assignments are missing then the phone goes away until academics are right again i do think your heart is in the right place and phones are seriously impacting children's attention span capabilities in general but in this day and age not having a phone for much longer is going to lead to much higher levels of social exclusion from her peers it probably already is tbh from a useful outlook maybe this could not only be a very much appreciated and memorable christmas present this year but also a valuable learning experience for you as parents to teach her about self control and limiting herself to a certain amount of phone time while also still prioritizing school responsibilities first and also establishing your rules for internet and phone safety it might be better to start this lesson at this age while you have more control to monitor what she's up to and she while still puts more weight into what you say

we raised two daughters right as this whole thing took off i e late s early s what we learned even then was that kids who did not have a phone got shut out of social life especially on weekends; both of ours would go to school on monday to find that their friends all got together on saturday after someone texted a group or they were just all chatting all weekend it became really pernicious and we finally gave in when they were i think and the younger one got a phone earlier imo it's as important for kids today to have access to chat as it was for teens to have a home phone in the s without it they are going to be left out that said i *don't* think it's necessary at all for them to have social media access that's another issue entirely you can limit phone use by literally taking it away from them at night or using parental controls or setting time limits filters on your network but these days *not* having a way to participate in group chats especially is going to be a social challenge well before th grade in my experience because it was a decade ago too

yea you could be doint a disservice if you’re not prepared to give her more access to these spaces as she gets older you’ve basically cut her off form being able to communicate with her peers about what could be common interests and you aren’t giving her the opportunity to make the kind of choices that you feel you’ve raised her to make she may already feel alienated from other kids already and she’s going to have to make extra effort to find her place among them socially since she’s not going to be able to connect with them on a basis of shared interests parental controls are a available if you feel that she’s too impressionable to navigate youtube for appropriate content and other social spaces i think monitoring her use of these things instead of completely restricting them until proven necessary would be best compromise in this situation let her have a phone as well access to roblox and youtube and see if her behavior stays the same or if it’s going to cause her adhd symptoms to flare up and go from there edit don’t let her have tiktok though that dopamine pile will have her face plastered to her screen i know from personal experience because tiktok is who told me i had adhd in the first place after only one week on it the algorithm knows it’s users

i think to an extent she probably does feel quite isolated regardless of our feelings about phones and the internet they have become an integral part of daily life for the younger generations there likely is a gap between her and her peers because of how online the culture of this youngest generation is and i’m willing to bet there’s probably a lot of things she’s not exactly “in” on with the rest of them because of that but your intentions are good and i still think that limiting access is healthier in general especially after you mentioning that she has adhd and impulse issues all that stuff really does exacerbate the issue to a hefty extent particularly social media i’ve found it’s done a lot to decrease the attention spans of people by a ridiculous amount maybe there’s a compromise here where she can have limited access to a device and the internet in moderate quantities that way she’s not as left out i also think that if you make internet and phone use a very rare thing for her what will eventually happen is when she finally does get a phone because in this day and age she’ll probably eventually get one in her teens she’ll go crazy overboard with it in response i see the same thing in kids whose parents completely banned all tv or in kids whose parents forbid all soda and candy the minute their kids got access to those things they went crazy with overconsumption because they were never normalized to consume these particular things in moderation in a healthy manner you don’t want a phone the internet to become that sort of thing for her

keep her off socials and away from internet access as long as possible i don’t have time to link articles now but there is a great deal of scientifically studied relevant information to support that adolescents can be harmed greatly by having that kind of access there is no upside other than convenience keep her entertained in other ways letting her learn online navigation under your direct supervision is wise and prudent at her age keep it up

my daughter is the same age and we let her have hours of ipad time to play roblox or watch a movie or use fb messenger kids etc each friday and saturday night that’s the only time she uses her ipad you could “ease” her into it other than that i’d say you’re doing the right thing many children at our school are the same don’t have phones etc and i want to keep it that way for as long as possible

i feel you should meet in the middle why not a talk about internet creeps safe online play and behaviour and then roblox in the living room where you can kinda overhear if she messes up with frequent refresh talks about the creeps and expected behaviour it’s what i did for ages i limit roblox time to like an hour occasionally and prefer when she meets up with real life friends in there to play as for phone i’m a meanie and don’t give till th grade and it’s still just wifi for a few years but the kids have tablets and the yo uses facebook kids messenger just like yours is we’re an adhd house too so we have to limit electronics as they just literally can’t self limit so like even the teens phone has x amount of tiktok youtube time daily but unlimited communication etc and she even agrees it’s needed we tried unlimited over summer and it just doesn’t work yet

dealing with a recent year old adhd child who does not have these limits i don't think your decisions are wrong i think you should expect your child will probably have access as she gets older at other kid's houses like sleepovers etc assuming you allow them i think you'll still need to have those talks about the problems with technology because it's still there just not as often in her life however as long as your daughter is diagnosed and receiving help therapy or meds for her adhd i don't think you're doing anything wrong

my son got his phone when he was in th grade and that was only because he would be home alone for about minutes until my wife got home from work we do not let him have social media he is now and still no social media when we tried letting him have it he did some stupid stuff that could have gotten him in a lot of trouble he also used social media messaging to get drugs and alcohol they apparently use snapchat to order whatever they want so this has lead to my son having a drug and alcohol addiction he’s already been in outpatient drug and alcohol counseling and therapy my suggestion if you don’t think they are ready for it then don’t do it or you can get a phone and put a lot of restrictions on it just be careful

i won’t bother reading replies of pearl clutching “how dare you deprive your child of mush brain inducing technology she might get good grades and not suffer from anxiety and depression like the rest of our kids ” in greta thunberg voice *how dare you * i always told my girls that i’m not others parents and they don’t make our rules do what you think is correct for her age the second you give her unsupervised and unlimited access to the internet say goodbye to childhood innocence other kids probably have spoiled that already many parents just hand the tech to the kid and never have to parent again you’re taking a difficult approach but doing the right thing is never easy i not only restrict access but also monitor activity because they’re not adults they often get in over their head and are put in adult situations as a girl she will likely face bullying become insecure about herself get into trends that are destructive or inappropriate when you do give her a phone look at monitoring apps like ourpact and bark you can control some of what she sees and does on her device

technology is a part of the world we live in most of the upcoming careers take place in the tech and gaming industries not allowing exposure and familiarity to these things puts a child at a disadvantage i dealt with a lot of these kids in college and had to teach so many of them how to use basic computer skills because their parents had sheltered them so much from tech stuff i was an older non traditional student and couldn't believe these kids didn't have basic life skills with a computer phone also as someone with adhd who is also a mother to adhd children i have never found strict regulation to be effective it has only ever made impulse control issues worse when we feel like something is limited or off limits to us instead of being able to freely access it then it makes us super anxious and more prone to lash out my children have free access to their devices in their free time and some days they will use them a lot some days they won't touch them and will spend all day outside or crafting
